column4: I just noticed that my home directory had 755 for permissions.  Why would Ubuntu have that for default?  I changed to 750..  comments?
maybe you or somone has been messing with chmod. I have mine as 600. Having some files in $HOME marked as executable may cause issues
I have a funny feeling its the CPU...
what service(s) do(es) the server run?
I appreciate your interest in troubleshooting, but I simply need to know if there is a way to capture kernel panics
try in /var/log/dmesg.0    I believe it is the dmesg from the previous boot
Looked around .. no luck.  I think I have to somehow mount a tty to a serial connection on another server.  This way I can scroll through the last kernel panic.
Lubuntu 12.04 isn't even ay LTS :( sad times
Xubuntu 12.04 is supported as long as Ubuntu 12.04 is. Lubuntu 12.04 is not LTS
Thats not ture.  Xubuntu is 3, Ubuntu is 5
wait, you are right. My bad
fresh install then restore data from backup
